text: Back then, this is years ago, I couldn't afford secrets. I just had chores. With toothbrush in mouth she moves her hair around, tryin one way, then another. INT. DAISY’S HOUSE AUNT’S BEDROOM. DAY Daisy, dressed, on her knees, helps her elderly Aunt pull stockings up over her thick legs.

As a child, growing up, we had been rich. And then -- well, we weren’t. EXT. DAISY’S HOUSE PORCH. DAY. Daisy comes out onto the porch followed by two Scottie do the screen door slams shut behind her. The dogs start bar at the noise; she ignores them.

And like most people during the Depression, I now lived each day as it came, no longer expecting anything. She carries an empty milk bottle; with her foot -- she’s this so many times before - she flips open the top lid of white wooden box on the porch. She takes out full milk bottle from the box, replacing it with the empty one. INT. DAISY’S HOUSE KITCHEN. DAY. Daisy stirs a pot of hot cereal on the stove, as she star at the coffee percolating in the little glass bubble on t top of the coffee pot.

Waiting -- for nothing. The Aunt, at the table, turns a page of a tired-looking, thumbed and old magazine.  INT. DAISY’S HOUSE HALLWAY. DAY. The telephone in the hallway begins to ring; and two Scot dogs suddenly start barking.
And then... The Aunt looks at Daisy, wondering who that could be? INT. DAISY’S HOUSE HALLWAY. DAY. Daisy answers the telephone.

(into the phone) Hello? Yes. What?? (to the yapping dogs) Sh-sh!! Be quiet. (into the phone) Sinus? INT. DAISY’S HOUSE KITCHEN. DAY. Daisy takes the pot off the stove and begins to serve the her mind far away. The dogs are yapping.
(to the dogs) Sh-sh...
(seeing her face) Did someone die?
No. No one died... INT. DAISY’S BEDROOM. DAY DAISY rifles through clothes on hangers in her closet; sh takes out a dress on a hanger, holds it up, looks it over puts it back, and takes out another.

I wasn’t the first relative his Mother called that day. Maybe not even the tenth.  INT. DAISY’S HOUSE, STAIRCASE/ LIVING ROOM. DAY. Daisy descends the stairs. She peeks around the corner, and smiles nervously at her Aunt, sitting in the living room.

I won’t be long. As Daisy disappears, the Aunt struggles to get herself up out of her chair. EXT. DAISY’S HOUSE PORCH. DAY. A large car is parked in front of the house; an Aide stan by the passenger door, and doffs his hat to Daisy. EXT. DAISY’S HOUSE, CAR. DAY. Once in, Daisy turns back toward the house, sees her Aunt peeking out around the lace curtain in the window. The Aunt nervously ‘waves.’ Daisy smiles nervously, and g a very faint wave back.
But I was around. The car begins to drive off. INT. CAR. DAY. The car drives down a long tree-lined driveway. Daisy sits in the backseat, her hands nicely folded on he lap. She stares straight ahead.
His Mother said he needed someone to take his mind off his work. Why she thought I could do that, I had no idea.
(after a nervous sigh, to the driver) We're fifth -- or sixth cousins. Depends on how you count...
I suppose he’s related to half of everybody up here. (looks at her through the mirror, reaches into his pocket) Cigarette?
No. No, I don’t. Thanks. Aide puts his cigarettes away. She looks out the window.

I figured I’d spend the afternoon there, and after having thoroughly bored him to death, go quietly back to my quiet life. EXT. DRIVEWAY. CONTINUOUS. The car pulls up in front of a mansion, Springwood. Other cars and a few military vehicles are parked along the dri A few cars drive off, others are arriving - this seems to a busy place. INT. HALLWAY. DAY. AN AIDE leads Daisy down the hallway which is full of peo working, sitting at make-shift desks, speaking in hushed important-sounding voices. Others are typing ... Aide 3 i speaking on the telephone in French. Daisy has to step ov phone cables that run across the floor. No one pays any attention to her.

But that’s not what happened. A door opens down the hall and a man comes out with a pie of paper and practically runs down the hall. Daisy has to get out of his way. The Aide leads her by the arm now.
He's not been feeling well. Sinuses. Daisy nods, she knows this.
Seems to happen every time, the second he comes home. They reach an imposing door, and the Aide knocks, waits, opens the door.

Mr. President? The Aide guides Daisy into the study. DAISY is hesitant. INT. STUDY. DAY. FRANKLIN D. ROOSEVELT sits behind his desk, turned away, deep even profound thought. DAISY enters, and the door is behind her. All the bustle of the hallway is gone. All we hear is the tic of the clock on the mantelpiece. She stands, self-conscious. He continues to concentrate. The warm glow of the desk is him. Lost in some other world, he takes off his glasses, his eyes, a lonely sigh -- unaware that anyone is watchin rare peek into the toll his office takes. She nervously waits for him to notice her. Then she 'coug Franklin swivels his chair around and sees her; at first doesn’t recognize her.
Daisy. What a rare treat. I hope my mother didn't force this on you.
She said everyone else was away.
Did she? She shouldn’t have said that. How nice to see you. How long has it been?
Oh, years. The Dows’ wedding, sir. In Rhinebeck?
Oh, were you there?
Where would you like me to sit?

There’s tea... I think there’s still tea. Will you..?  She goes and pours tea for herself. Franklin opens a desk drawer, takes out a flask. Before h can pour, he touches his forehead, closes his eyes, reach for his handkerchief and blows his nose -- painfully. Dai watches all of this with interest. He then pours liquor i his tea.
I can do this because my mother's not here. He laughs. She doesn’t believe in sinus medicine... He looks at her, then decides not to offer, and puts the flask back in the drawer.
(sips his tea) That’s better. Do you collect stamps, Daisy?
I - don't. He reaches across his desk and picks up a large stamp alb and a magnifying glass.

Come and look at these... She politely goes to the desk, looks for a chair, finds o and brings it to in front of the desk, where Franklin, magnifying glass in hand, has begun looking over his stam He hands her the magnifying glass. Daisy ‘studies’ the stamps through the magnifying glass - there are stamps of rich colors and exotic and distant pl and peoples. She turns the page -- and the stamps on this page are of people of today --General Franco; Josef Stalin; Haile Selassie of Ethiopia; Mussolini of Italy and so forth.
I suppose you’ve met pretty much everyone of these... She looks closely at a stamp of Hitler through the magnif glass.
Not every one. Not yet.
They're -- fascinating. The door opens and a secretary, MISSY, enters without knocking. She carries a file. On seeing Daisy:
Excuse me, I should have knocked. She sets a paper in front of him. As he signs, Missy brie looks over Daisy who is pretending to look at the stamps.

(As he skims the letter, to Missy, incredulous) I actually wrote this? (Missy just waits, then to Daisy) My cross, Daisy, is that I am too nice. (To Missy) But -- we need the Senator’s vote. Don’t we? Why can’t politicians just be honest? (He smiles at Daisy, then as he signs, explaining Daisy to Missy) My cousin. Missy ‘smiles’ at her, and Daisy smiles back. As she continues to 'study' the stamps, she hears the doo close and Missy leave. Then she notices Franklin looking her. She turns to a page of the album. Franklin leans ove and looks.

Those are from Africa. She slowly turns the pages. They say that's the highest waterfall in the world. She turns another page and stops--. Daisy looks at the stamps, then looks at him, smiles. She turns the page and looks at a stamp.
(seriously and proper) I understand Africa can get very hot. She looks at him. She makes him smile.

Very hot, Daisy. When sees him smiling, she likes this -- she’s doing what she’s supposed to be doing. She turns the page. Franklin once again presses his fingers to his forehead - relieving the sinuses. She watches him, concerned.
Would you like me to go?

No. Please. I wouldn’t. Franklin sips his spiked tea, lights a cigarette -- both which make him feel better for a moment, and so he turns attention back to enjoying watching Daisy look at the sta album.
(pointing out a stamp) This one’s pretty. I'd like to go there.
Where is that?
Well. To be honest, I’d like to go almost anywhere. This makes him laugh.

The President spent a lot of time that spring in Hyde Park-on-Hudson. EXT. DRIVEWAY / FRONT OF HOUSE . DAY. President Roosevelt's motorcade is arriving. A flurry of excitement, as aides hurry out of their cars before they even stopped, and rush to go and set up.

In Europe there would certainly be another war, one we would be dragged into, whether we liked it or not. Franklin smiles in the passenger seat of a limousine, as Mother and servants come out to greet him.
Here at home, he said, everyone was just shouting at each other. Daisy stands under a tree, at a distance, watching all th excitement of his arrival.
So the President spent an awful lot of time that spring in Hyde Park On Hudson. He said -- I helped him forget --. Daisy waves to Franklin.
-- ‘the weight of world’.

A microphone is being set up on Franklin's desk by technicians as he looks over a speech. Franklin’s Mother straightens her son’s tie, smooths his hair, fusses with collar -- still taking care of her boy.
(a joke to the technicians) Will someone please tell her -- it’s radio? The technicians laugh. Mother keeps fussing.
His Mother said he’d run the whole country from here if he could. A crowd has formed in the open doorway to listen to his speech.
But he couldn’t. Not with how things were -- so many people out of work.  10.
Quiet please...
I think that means you, Mother. INT. KITCHEN. DAY. A radio is on in the kitchen:

(on the radio) But I know many of you have lost your jobs or have seen your friends or members of your families lose their jobs. In the kitchen five or six servants stand, paying rapt attention to the radio broadcast. DAISY’S VO. Everyone scared. No one knowing what was going to happen. INT. HALLWAY. DAY. We move out of the kitchen and through the living room wh military men sit listening to a large radio.

(on the radio) and I do not propose that the Government shall pretend not to see these things. INT. LIVING ROOM / STUDY. DAY. We move down the hallway and Franklin’s voice on the radi gets fainter and fainter until we reach a group of staff servants in the study’s doorway and through these craning necks and bobbing heads we see Franklin giving the chat i the microphone:
But I conceive the first duty of government is to protect the economic welfare of all the people in all sections and in all groups...  11.
And everyone looking to him. Daisy sits in a corner arm chair, magnifying glass in han looking at stamps, while listening to Franklin make his broadcast.
In front of the house, the President sits in a chair on t steps as a local German-American brass band (lederhosen, etc.) under a banner ("Hyde Park German-American Friendsh Society”) plays for him.

And even here he couldn’t get completely away. They all wanted something from him. The local labor union, the Hyde Park Chamber of Commerce, the German-American Friendship Band. He catches sight of Daisy in the crowd of servants and st watching the band from the driveway.

And all he wanted -- was to relax. He smiles, and winks at her. INT. FRANKLIN'S CAR. DAY. Franklin drives. He pushes a button on a small contraptio and a lit cigarette appears as if by magic. Daisy is with him in the passenger seat.

That spring I learned to smoke. Daisy takes the lit cigarette out of the contraption; sta to hand it to Franklin, but impulsively takes a puff firs herself, then smiling, she gives the cigarette to him.
Another day. They drive down a country road through a woo where trees are being lumbered. Following behind them is State Trooper car.  12.
Each time he came home, he’d telephone and ask: Daisy where would you like to go today? And I would always answer -- ‘anywhere.’
Another day. The car climbs the hill with the police car right behind.
His wife, he said, didn’t like to take drives. I learned the names of birds and trees I’d seen my whole life. We drove along country roads, up hills, through woods, through fields.
The two cars drive through a field.
He'd had the car built so it could be driven with just the hands.
Franklin brakes with his hands, then, using only his hand accelerates. Daisy in the front seat watches his hands closely. Then she turns and looks back at the police car behind.
A Police Car always followed just behind.
A Police Car follows Franklin's car.
That is, until one day...  13.

Franklin drives the car up a very bumpy road. Franklin ha his left arm out the window, and with his left hand he is gesturing behind him -- waving the police escort away. Da doesn’t see this. Daisy turns and looks back, where she sees the police car pulling off the road and turning around. She turns back to Franklin as he drives.
Where’s the police car going? EXT. BUMPY PATH. DAY. Franklin maneuvers the car up a steep dirt road in the wo The car shakes from the bumps.

Oh, they don't follow all the time. Sometimes they have to go and catch a crook or something, I suppose. He laughs. Daisy laughs. The car continues up through the woods and comes to a slo stop on the hillside overlooking the valley.
Franklin turns off the engine. For a moment there is only sound of the birds and the wind.
What a lovely spot. We've not been here before.
No. I've been saving this.
What a beautiful view. As she looks off, he leans over and turns on the car radi

I like this song.  14. As the song plays, Franklin smiles one of his big smiles Daisy, then dispenses a lit cigarette from the little machine. He puffs. The cigarette smoke curls out of the c as they listen. Daisy is lost in the song, in the view, in the swirling s she hums along with the song. Then she notices that Frank looking at her; he takes her hand in his. He her puts her on his thigh. And leaves it there. Daisy looks down at her hand on Franklin’s thigh. She loo him, looking out the window, smoking. He takes her hand, and puts it on his groin. She hesitates, then begins to unbutton his trousers; chec see if he objects or if this is what he wants. He just looks off, smoking. Then without looking, he help unbuckling his belt. From the perspective of the backseat, it soon becomes cle she is rubbing him, masturbating him. He closes his eyes, bites his lip, as he looks off into t woods. And after a moment of this, it is clear that he comes. Pa Daisy doesn’t know what to do. She looks at him; he begin button up his trousers, buckle his belt. She looks away into the woods, not sure whether to be embarrassed or not. Franklin finishes buttoning and tries to hand her his poc handkerchief. She doesn’t notice at first; her mind racin He touches her knee, which startles her; she sees the off handkerchief, and takes it.
I’m sorry. I’m sorry. I’m--
I’m the one who should apologize... With his handkerchief, she begins to wipe her dress and h hands.
Should we go back?  15. Daisy nods, as she wipes.

I knew, even without him saying anything that we were now -- not just fifth cousins -- but very good friends. He turns off the car radio and a telephone rings. INT. DAISY’S HOUSE HALLWAY/ KITCHEN. DAY. Daisy is on the telephone, giggling like a schoolgirl, unconsciously playing her hair, smiling, transfixed by th conversation.

(into the phone) As soon as I can get away. (She laughs.) She hangs up and as she fixes her hair she goes into the kitchen. The moment she enters the kitchen, she stops preening. He her Aunt sits at the table; a good-sized lunch finished i front of her. Daisy starts to pick up her Aunt’s dishes a take them to the sink.
Who was that?
The President wishes to see me. (and this answers everything) And he’s the President. Aunt looks at her. Daisy begins to wash the dishes.

He wishes to show me a new -- stamp. Daisy washes a pot. EXT. DAISY’S HOUSE PORCH. DAY. DAISY runs out of the door, the screen door slamming behi and she hurries into her own car and begins to drive off.  19 16.

And so time passed. Time measured now in Franklin’s visits home. INT. FRANKLIN'S CAR. DAY. Franklin's car as he drives it back up a very narrow, ste bumpy road. Daisy is at his side. She looks back. They ar alone.
Look at that -- the police have left us alone yet again. EXT. A HILLSIDE. DAY.
They seem to have a sixth sense about that.

They do, don't they? EXT. DIRT ROAD. DAY. The car comes up a steep incline, it is shaking and bounc through ruts, and over rocks. Daisy looks at Franklin, smiles, as she bounces, holding He reaches down and puts the car into first gear and driv little farther up. The road gets even narrower, trees lim bang against the windshield.

Where are we going? EXT. TOP COTTAGE. DAY. And there, suddenly revealed, hidden from the road is a_ stone cottage. She looks at him, confused: what is this? He stops the car, and turns off the engine.
It’s lovely. They sit in the car looking at the cottage.  17.
I had it built. It's where I’1l retire. I’1ll write those detective books I'm always talking about. She looks at him and nods.

Go look around. She gets out of the car, and goes toward the house; she c believe her eyes. Franklin's car door opens and first one and then the seco leg are lifted out, held tight by leg braces. EXT. TOP COTTAGE. DAY. Daisy runs excitedly through the cottage, opens the slidi glass doors and bursts out onto the porch.
It’s heaven!! Franklin has made it to the porch. He looks off across th valley:
I have been thinking, Daisy... He hesitates.
What? (no response) What have you been thinking?
That I.. I’d like to--. To share with you -- this. She stands across the porch from him, watching him.
When I have to be away...You know I have to be away. He turns to her, she nods.
Should you ever miss me...? She looks at him.  18.
You think you might miss me? She smiles -- of course she will.
(teasing her) Well, if you ever do --
(interrupting) Do you ever miss me? He looks at her, then:

I always do. (about the house) A place to come. And be alone. (he smiles at her) And miss me... She looks at him lovingly. Franklin just smiles. She clumsily hugs him, which nearly knocks him over; she grabs him as he totters; he just keeps smiling at her.

head_text.subj: CONTINUOUS STEADICAM.INT. STUDY/ HALLWAY/ LIVING ROOM /

text: Daisy, in Franklin’s study, pulls out a drawer of the des fumbles through some papers, and takes out a small bottle aspirin.

By now everyone was used to me. I was the cousin who’s always visiting. No one ever even asked me why that was. She opens the door to the Living Room where she finds Franklin's Mother, with Tommy QUALTERS, a copy of Scribne magazine in her hand. Around them, staff are cleaning and moving furniture, flowers, etc.
Has he read this?  19.
I believe he has.

(reading from the magazine, as she moves toward the Hallway with Daisy and Qualters) "If one could choose, from all possible British personalities, the two who might make the best impression upon Americans -- King George and Queen Elizabeth would not even make the short list." (She looks up, outraged) How dare they talk about Royalty like this! The Hallway is packed and buzzing with tides of servants tradesmen carrying flowers and various packages. Everyone seems busy and in a hurry.

No King of England had ever visited America before. But now he was coming -- to Hyde Park on Hudson. We move off, following Maid 2 who hurries towards the Kit clutching a large vase, taking us into the ‘backstage’ ar of the house which is also teeming with activity. Maid 2 almost collides with Maid 1 who is rushing towards the Di Room. We follow Maid 1 who nervously approaches Mother, w by now has reached the Dining Room.
Mrs Roosevelt, we appear not to have enough plates.
What??
Franklin warned us, today, stay out of Mother’s way.
We don't have enough plates. Someone miscounted.
You tell me this now? Mother's English Butler now hurries in.  20.
Mrs Astor has called again.

Mrs Astor. She'll have plates. We'll borrow hers. (Mother starts to head off towards the Kitchen) On second thought -- we’ll ask her cook. Mrs Astor is so rich, she doesn’t know what she has. The Butler hesitates -- this is all too much for him -- t he straightens his coat and we follow him as he heads off into the Hallway, where two black servants, Nelson and Thomas, have entered from outside, carrying their bags, a dressed in their travel clothes. The Butler stops and stares at them.
(to the Butler) Good morning. The Butler looks them up and down.

Could you tell us which way’s the kitchen? The Butler ignores their question and heads off at speed towards the Kitchen to protest their presence. We follow the Butler into the Kitchen where there is a chaotic scene of preparation for that evening’s dinner. Dishes being prepared, vegetables cut, pots boiling, with cooks and cooks’ helpers working at double-speed. Mother is inspecting a vast and ornate dessert. A female stands next to her, waiting for the verdict.
Good. Good. But is ‘good’ the best we can do? They are royalty. Maid 1 is holding the kitchen telephone. With her hand ov the receiver, she calls to Mother:
We can borrow the plates, ma’am!
Thank God for rich neighbors.  21. Maid 2 appears out of breath.
(to Maid 2) What is it?
Their rooms are ready, ma’am.
(she heads off to check on their rooms) ) The poor dears are going to be exhausted. Daisy stands at the sink, she takes a water glass off of shelf, and turns on the tap.
(wiping the perspiration from her brow, to a Scullery Maid) ‘Poor dears.’
Exhausted my arse.

I'd watch what I said, if I were you. The Butler follows Mother out of the Kitchen. Maid 2 sticks her tongue out at the departed Butler. The Cook then clears her throat and gestures to Maid 2, t Daisy is standing right there. Maid 2 then turns to Daisy, and smiles. Daisy, filling th glass at the sink, ‘smiles’ back and then leaves via the door towards the Lawn.

The only quiet place left to work was outside. EXT. LAWN. DAY. Daisy, water glass and pill bottle in hand, heads across lawn toward Franklin and Missy who sit together at a heal distance from all of the chaos of the house.  22. Piles of papers and files surround Franklin who is just finishing the article in the magazine as Daisy reaches th phone on a very long lead is on the ground next to him.
Missy, have you seen this?
Scribner's? Not this month. He hands her the magazine to read.
(seeing the glass and pills) What are those for?
He has a headache.
(to Franklin) You do?
His sinuses again. Happens this time every year.
I know that. Daisy hands Franklin the glass and a couple of aspirin.
(to Franklin) You didn’t say anything about a headache.
He's not going to trouble you with everything, Missy. You have enough on your plate.
What does that mean? Aide 2 has brought Franklin a few messages, which he open and reads as:
It means -- you take very good care of me, Missy. (then) I mean you both do. (MORE )
mM.  23. FRANKLIN (cont'd) (to the Aide, about the message) I‘1ll call in the morning. They -- can wait. Can’t they?
They can, sir. Aide 2 heads back as Qualters now reaches them, having crossed the lawn from the house.
They have left New York. Estimated time of arrival: 6pm.
Good. Both Daisy and Missy are listening now.
The State Police are predicting crowds of up to three hundred thousand along their route here.
(to Franklin) You're smiling.
I am. It means a lot -- that they’re welcomed. It says something.
I thought you'd appreciate that, sir.
(to Franklin) And what does it say?
That maybe, Daisy, their visit will be a success. And that is very important. He suddenly looks at her and smiles.
To show the whole world that we are the best of friends. Qualters has started to head back, stops.  24.
And in each town, as the Royals drive through, we're ringing church bells.
Excellent. (then shouts to him as he goes) Set up the drinks tray in the library. Qualters hearing this looks pained.
Is this something you've addressed with your mother?
I'm trying not to address it with my mother, which is why I'm asking him to do it.
A PLUMBER is on his knees installing a new toilet seat. Franklin's MOTHER stands over him watching everything he does. He finishes the last screw, looks to Mother:
Real rosewood. Still got the smell.

Is that why it cost so much? He smells the toilet seat. Rubs his hand around it -- sho off its smoothness. A couple of Maids stand in the doorway watching, as Mothe hesitates then leans down and opens and closes the seat a times to test it out.
Qualters is setting up a drinks tray. The door is open and a severe looking woman, Eleanor, sto in the doorway. She just looks at what is being set up.
I’m just doing what I’m told.  25. We notice MAID 1 in the corner cleaning the curtains. The look at her, and she hurries out.

(about the Maid leaving and the drinks tray) So much for your little secret... INT. LIVING ROOM. DAY. Eleanor comes out of the study and heads down the hallway only to pass Franklin’s Mother, who is furious, on her wa the study, MAID 1 right behind her. Mother and Eleanor look at each other:
Good morning, Mother.
Good morning. Mother reaches the study door, and goes in without knocki
We are not going to serve the King of England - a cocktail!! The Maid, seeing Eleanor listening, closes the door to th study.
Missy continues to read the magazine. Franklin is finishi correcting a speech.
(to Aide 1) Mike, read this over the phone to Harry. If he thinks it sounds all right have him hand it personally to the Speaker.
I will, sir. He hands him the speech. Missy looks to Daisy who is lost in thought, and just sta at Franklin. Eleanor joins them with a tray of coffee.  26.
Who'd like coffee? (to Franklin, as she pours coffee) Your Mother has now told me for the tenth time -- not to call her Royal Highness -- Elizabeth.
She’s told me that too. (turns to Daisy) Daisy? Daisy? Hello? Anyone home in there?
(coming to) What?? Oh yes. She told me that too.
(to Franklin) I told her who did she think I was?
(to Eleanor) I think she knows.
(to Daisy) You're just staring at the President.
I’m not. I wasn’t. (to Missy) What do you want?
Eleanor’s just brought out fresh coffee. She was asking if you'd like any. She’s staring again.
What?? I’m not.
She's blushing. Leave her alone, Missy. My husband lives for the adoring eyes of young women. We all know this. She smiles.  27.
(‘joking’) Let’s change the subject, shall we?
Don’t tell me you’re embarrassed. That day, I would like to see.
I didn’t say I was embarrassed.
Daisy’s blushing again. Daisy is very lost now, and as she looks from one to the other.
What is she thinking? What’s going on in that mind?
What are they doing? He has looked off and we see what he is seeing: three lar tractors with mowers attached are idling in a row across lawn.
They've been told to mow. They’re waiting for you to move.
Why didn’t someone tell me this? Were they just going to sit there? They start picking things up. Daisy stands and starts to Franklin. As they head off:
(new subject, to Franklin) Hick called. For this morning's Royal visit to the World's Fair -- you won't believe this -- she'd been ordered to produce five thousand children overnight.
What? Why?
As buffers for holding back the crowds.  28.
No.
Children. She couldn't believe it. Police said that's what they'd done in Washington and Canada. Put the kids between the King and Queen and the crowds. The Girl Scouts refused outright--.
Good for them.
They said their girls had taken an awful beating in DC! Laughter from the group as they get set to head off.
So she finally got some Boy Scouts! More laughter.
But when they were pushed, they pushed back! Started something like ten fist fights!
Poor Hick.
When she finally got back to her office, she kicked off her shoes, opened her window and shouted out: ‘God damn the King and Queen!” All laughing hard.
Maybe we'll be saying the same thing tomorrow! More laughing. Daisy, 'laughing', watches Eleanor laugh w abandon.
‘Hick’ was short for Lorena Hickock. One of those friends of Eleanor’s Franklin called - -- ‘she men.’  29. Eleanor pushes Franklin in his wheelchair across the lawn Daisy follows, watching Eleanor:
People said their marriage was troubled and unhappy. That they lived mostly separate lives. Daisy watches Franklin reach and pat Eleanor’s hand as sh pushes him.

But I never saw that. That’s now how they seemed when they were together. Eleanor has said something that has made Franklin laugh again. They clearly know how to make each other laugh. INT. STABLE. DAY. Missy and Eleanor now sit together, and drink the coffee Eleanor brought. It's dark inside, with shafts of light through the cracks in the wood. Daisy is with the women, she keeps looking over at Franklin who sits alone, a sing light bulb on overhead as he continues to work on papers. Aide stands with him. Missy is still reading the magazine:
(reads from article) "A large part of the country still believes that Edward, Duke of Windsor, is the rightful owner of the British throne --
“Thrones?’ ‘Kings and Dukes.’ It all sounds like the Middle Ages. There is a knock on the door. They women look at each oth is it Mrs. Roosevelt looking for them?
(without looking up) Is it my mother?
See who it is, Daisy. Daisy goes and peeks through the crack.  30.
(back to Franklin) Tommy . Franklin nods, and Daisy opens the door and Qualters snea in, Daisy closing the door behind him.
(still reading the article, having looked up) A very chastened-looking Tommy.
As he should be. He was on his way to set up a drinks tray in the library.
Really?
(to Franklin) Did you tell him to do that?
I did not and Missy is my witness. Qualters stands next to Franklin.
Mind if I sit in here with you?
Gotten a little warm inside? He sits on a nearby bench.
Your mother -- well, she’s very much in control. The women listen to this.
(as he works) What’s all this I hear about a drinks tray? Qualters looks to Eleanor, then:  31.

I’ve been told that my idea of setting one out was not a very considered one... EXT. STABLE. DAY. Aide 1 is running a phone line from the house to the stab Other Aides now come in and out of the door. INT. STABLE. DAY. Inside the stables, it’s become almost an office; there a the papers and files that had been with Franklin on the l
(as he works) I was told this King didn’t even want the job. Franklin's engagement gets the women’s attention.
Really?

Of course he is... INT. HALLWAY / DINING ROOM. EVENING. The soup course is about to be served. A waiter holds a stopwatch at his side. A Maid whispers:
What are you doing with that?

(under his breath) We've been told the Queen is served exactly 30 seconds after the King. The King is served his soup, and the Waiter starts the stopwatch ticking. Suddenly we hear an enormous crash. A serving tray with a pile of plates has collapsed, start everyone.
What happened?
(holding the King’s soup) I don't know. No one touched it.

I su-su-suppose an angel just passed - a ve-ve-ry clumsy one. He smiles at his joke. Franklin leads the laughter, and g Bertie a big nodding smile. The King is very pleased with himself. Mother is embarrassed but trying not to show it. Franklin looks to Eleanor who smiles, and then nods her h she has appreciated the King’s sense of humor and grace.
(to Cameron, about the King’s joke) ) That was very good...  65. Maids 1 & 2 have quickly started to clean up.
(to the other, explaining the crash) It’s the full moon. The Maid 1 nods.

(to a neighbor) I hope those weren't mine. (to Cameron, another neighbor, explaining) She didn't have enough plates. EXT. LAWN. EVENING. Missy and Daisy sit on a bench, under a tree; the house a front of them, and the music. Both look at the moon. Both
She doesn’t leave him alone. She doesn’t let him relax.
Is that what he tells you?
What?
Does he talk about her with you, Daisy?
With me? Why would he talk about his wife with me?
I don’t know how he stands it. Missy has finished her cigarette and tosses it on the gro and stands.
Stands what?
Eleanor's always off to places. Meetings. How he must miss it. Daisy tosses her cigarette down and stands.  66.
Miss what? Missy starts to head back to the house, Daisy right behin her.
Having a happy married life together.
I don’t think that is the President’s fault --.
I wasn’t saying--. I think it pains him more than we can know -- not having a wife to care for him. As they head toward the brightly lit house, we hear only their voices:
This morning she didn’t even know about his sinuses.
Didn’t she?
She said she didn’t. It’s sort of like they’ve become just -- friends. Just good friends.
She is a_ busy woman.
She's his wife... INT. DINING ROOM. EVENING. Franklin is telling the table the story of Bertie being g the choice of tea or a highball.

“My mother treats me in the exactly same way, Mr. President... But I too prefer a cocktail. Who wouldn't?” Great laughter; Bertie enjoys the attention and is smilin soaking it in.  67. Mother is not too keen about telling this story; and Elizabeth is a bit surprised. But the table finds it very funny. Eleanor especially is now laughing. Maid 1 is whispering in Mother's ear. INT. KITCHEN. EVENING. In the kitchen, Mr Johnson, Mother's English butler, stan his coat, holding his hat. An Aide is with him.
I apologize, Madam. For the timing.
I've tried to talk to him.

(very stiff, very proper, very English) Madam, I simply cannot stand by and watch the King of my country being served by....Negroes. For the first time we see the problem -- the two Negro waiters, Nelson and Thomas, stand in the corner listening this.
Mr. Johnson, you are the best butler we have. I understand the situation. (to Aide) Isn't there something we can do?
They came with--.
Me. Eleanor, sensing the problem, has followed them into the kitchen.
Mr Thomas and Mr. Nelson are part of the White House staff.
I realize that, Eleanor. What if we kept them in the kitchen?  68.
Mother, we’re not going to hide them in the kitchen.
Eleanor, why are you even involved in this?
You knew we were bringing help. You agreed.
I didn’t know they were -- them.
Either they go, or I go, Ma‘’am. Mother turns to Eleanor.
They are not going anywhere. As long as I am here.

Daisy and Missy now at the window to the dining room, pee in. Through the window -- The Negro servants enter, Mother an Eleanor behind them; Eleanor smiling to herself, triumphantly. We look around the table, Franklin laughing Bertie listening to someone on his right, etc. Missy touches Daisy's shoulder to move her along:
Do you need a ride home--?
(still staring into the window) No. Along the house, the English Butler, Johnson, bag in hand walking toward the front of the house and the road. Daisy stares into the window.

Look at him.  69. We see what she is looking at: Franklin is now leaning ov the table telling a story -- everyone is enthralled, then burst into laughter, including Eleanor. He is obviously i his element. DAISY’S VOICE They love him. MISSY’S VOICE Who doesn’t.
I suppose I better go.

I’1l walk you to your car. The two women head around the house. DAISY’S VOICE I can’t help but keep thinking about the King’s brother giving up his crown. For love. A real life Romeo and Juliet. Franklin and I talked about it. MISSY’S VOICE Did you? And what did he say, Daisy? DAISY’S VOICE He said that sort of thing was very English. MISSY’S VOICE Where’s your car?

A maid carries in a tray of food, as she approaches the K she trips and the plates are flung right past the King. Mother immediately looks at one of the Negro waiters, Tho who gestures that he didn’t do anything. The Maid is horrified. Silence. Then:
Nu-nu-number 2! Laughter Eleanor enjoying this, as Maids go to clean up t mess. 2nd Maid whispers to the lst, as if explaining it a  70.
I told you -- it’s the moon.

The full moon. The guests are all leaving, coming out of house, saying their good-byes to Mother. Chauffeurs and d are lined up with their cars. One by one their owners get and are driven off down the tree-lined lane. EXT. LAWN. EVENING. The military band are packing up their things. INT. HALLWAY/ LIVING ROOM. NIGHT. Franklin starts to wheel his chair from the hallway into living room. In the background, the final guests are leav
Let's go to my study. We'll be left alone in there. Unless you need to--.
No. No. Franklin stops.
Would you mind pushing? Bertie gets behind Franklin and pushes him into the livin room. Her Majesty has gone to bed?
She has. And -- your wife?
Who knows? (he laughs) I'm sure. INT. STUDY. NIGHT. Bertie pushes Franklin in, Franklin gestures that he shou close the door.  71.

Night cap? Mother's gone to bed. Still sitting in his wheelchair, he begins to make them drinks. I was worried for her....if one more thing went wrong... Smiles, hands Bertie a drink. (about the drink) ) They worry about me. My Mother and Eleanor. Both their fathers were nasty drunks. Cheers.
Cheers. They drink, Bertie is looking around the room.
Do you collect stamps?
I did. I have. I understand you are a serious stamp collector. Perhaps, you would show me some of your stamps.
You can’t be interested.
But I am --.

Don’t -- protest. Thank you for the thought, though. Toasts him. When I was a young man -- before my marriage of course -- I found that showing one’s stamps was a very helpful way to get a young woman’s attention.
Was it.

They have to sit close to you. Share the magnifying glass.  72. He ‘winks’ at Bertie. And smiles. But I suppose if your father’s the king... Who needs stamps? Bertie sips his drink. The Queen is certainly a lovely woman. Bertie looks up at him.
As is the first lady.

She’s a -- (choosing his words carefully) strong -- person (smiles) Some days you feel like you don’t even want to get out of bed -- but then these women, they won’t let you do that, will they? He looks at Bertie, who sips his drink and says:
No.

What do you do -- to be alone? Bertie looks confused. (explaining) I have my stamps... You need to give them (gestures to those outside -- wherever) a reason not to bother you. You can figure things out in the quiet of your own head. I open up my stamp books and that tells everyone not to bother me. Bertie nods. You were wonderful tonight, young man. Bertie is taken aback by this.  73.
What do you mean?
Just what I said. You were graceful. You were confident. You're going to be a very fine king. I'm sure of it.
I don't know what to say.
Your father would be very proud.
(‘smiling’) I’m not so certain about that. Franklin sips his drink, looking right into Bertie’s eyes

If I were your father, I’d be proud. They sip their drinks, Bertie looks around, thinking abou what to say. He smiles; FRANKLIN CONT’D I know -- some men have an entire home as their castle, I only get a study. (then) But then you must have many many castles. Bertie looks at him.
The Queen -- she’s... She worries so much. It’s been hard for her.
(a fact) Women worry.
I just stop listening to her sometimes. Forget I said that.
Forgotten.  74. Bertie takes a folded up piece of paper out of his inside jacket pocket, and looks at it.
(explaining) I’ve been asked to say things... He looks up and begins:

Such a war as we now co-co- contemplate --. The carnage, look at S-S-S-Spain. Ch-children -- b-b- bombed. Tha-tha-that’s what we can expect. It will b-b-be horrific. Beyond anything m-m-man has seen. Bertie takes a sip, then looks up at Franklin.

(he tries again) And yet we know some of your countrymen wi-wi-wi-sh my country i- i-i-i-ill... And w-w-want us to fail. And want me to fail wi-th-th- th you... (he looks away) This god damn st-st-stutter... He looks back into his drink.
What stutter? Bertie is surprised by this, looks closely at Franklin, t
This god damn polio. They look closely at each other.
Sometimes I think -- they des- deserve better than me. My -- ‘subjects.’ I’m sorry. I don’t know why-why I’m saying this to you. I’m s-s-supposed to be trying to convince you to help us.
Let me confess something now to you. Bertie looks at him.  75.
As you have been so -- honest with me. No one -- ever mentions to me that I can’t move my legs. It’s never referred to. Bertie is very intrigued by this.

Not by anyone. I used to think it was because they were embarrassed about it. Franklin starts to stand up out of his wheelchair; Bertie stands to help, Franklin waves him off. As he heads to hi desk, moving slowly on his braces, holding on to the back chairs. FRANKLIN (CONT’D) But now I think it’s because that’s not what they want to see. He sits at his desk, takes a cigarette (his reason for co to the desk), offers one to Bertie as he talks.

Of course we (gestures he and Bertie) think they (gestures everyone out there) see everything that we are. All our flaws. Or transgressions. Or failures. But that is not what they're looking to find when they look to us. And God help us if that ever changes. They look at each other. Think of the disappointment... when they find out what we really are. (smiles) Sometimes it might make one feel an imposter... He is lighting Bertie’s cigarette now so their faces are close. This last comment strikes home for Bertie.
(unable to look up as he speaks) They didn’t want me as their King.  76.

I didn’t know they voted for that in England. Bertie smiles. Franklin relaxes behind his desk. FRANKLIN (CONT’D) Pretending at times to be someone we know we aren’t. Young man, that’s what I’ve learned it takes to be a President. And I’m going to hazard a guess that it takes the same damn thing to be a king. He smiles that big smile, smoking his cigarette.

I’m thinking -- another drink? INT. LIVING ROOM / HALLWAY. NIGHT. The living room is empty; laughter is heard coming from t Study. Missy enters from the hallway, on her way to the study, having obviously been called. She stops when she sees Bertie, come out of the study, smiling to himself. He quietly closes the door behind him; he appears to be a somewhat changed man, at least for the moment -- a new sp in his step; a satisfied smile. At first he doesn’t notice Missy.
(after nearly bumping into her) Pardon me...

Sir. (corrects herself) I mean, Your Highness. (corrects herself again) Your Majesty... She curtseys. He smiles at her and she watches him head u the steps, two at a time.  77. INT. ELIZABETH’S BEDROOM. NIGHT. Bertie goes through the bathroom, and gently pushes the d open to Elizabeth's bedroom. Elizabeth asleep in bed. Bertie stands for a moment, then ‘coughs.’
You're still awake?
Mmmmmmm .
I think I'll go to sleep. It's late.
Why are you smiling? Are you drunk?
No. He's a very funny man. Has some wonderful jokes.
Like what? She sits up in bed.
(hesitates, then) I couldn't tell them to you. They're not meant for women.
They sound very 'funny.'
He liked my stories too. Concerned, she turns on bedside lamp.
What stories?
I-I-I told him about the coronation. About how they p-p-put the crown wrong way around. He laughs, she doesn't. And the stepping on my robe so I couldn't move.  78.
You shouldn't have told him that.
Why? He laughed.
We don't make fun of ourselves.
That's not true.
Not here. Of course he liked those stories, they make us look like fools.
They make us look like people!
Don't be naive, Bertie. Bertie goes and looks out the window and again there is t full moon.
He made fun of himself too. He said at the picnic tomorrow--
Oh god that picnic.
(sitting on the bed, smiling) He said that the Indians -- they were Eleanor's ideas. "One of my-my-my wife's crazy ideas." His Mother is furious about it. Franklin's just trying to keep it short.
He talks about his wife like that to you? I hope you didn't talk about me to him.
I didn't. I wouldn't do that. We didn't talk about you. (then) I asked him -- without mentioning you -- about these hot dogs? What's that about? You want to know what he said? (MORE )
BERTIE (cont'd) (she stares at him) He said he doesn't get the fuss. They're just a good thing to eat ata picnic. There's no 'meaning.' Nothing more.
You didn't say I was concerned?
No.
I'm not sure I believe you--.
That's not fair.
Three different women tonight asked me if I thought there could ever be an American queen. If we'd ever ‘allow' that.
That was rude.
Do you have a cigarette? I have smoked all of mine.
That won't help you sleep.
I know. He gives her a cigarette. Thank you. A light? He lights her cigarette. He nods.
I never wanted this life.
I know.
It’s hard.  80. Go to bed. I'll be fine. She smokes.
If there's a war -- and we know there will be -- he believes America could be persuaded to help.
Did you see some of the people here tonight? Hear their names? They're from Germany. Italy.
Their ancestors--
They're Irish. They're Jews. They hate us, Bertie!! They want to see us fall on our face!! They want to laugh at us!! She starts to cry.

I think you're wrong. I th-th- think we just need to be a little more confident. He gets up off the bed and heads back to his bedroom. Elizabeth is amazed, stunned by this new attitude; she ha never heard him talk like this before.

Goodnight. I'm not sure I can even sleep. (turns back to her) Finally, he patted me on the knee and said, ‘young ma-ma-man, it's time for you to go to bed." Like a father, I suppose. He's very happy that I am king. (Then one more thing) When he retires, he's going to write detective stories. I told him I love detective stories. She just looked at him. He’s built a cottage. He told me I could come and stay anytime. I love detective stories.  81. He closes the bathroom door behind him.

head_text.subj: INT. PINK BEDROOM. / EXT. FRONT OF HOUSE. NIGHT

text: Bertie, in his pajamas now, sits in a chair in the corner smokes in the dark. He gets up and goes to look at the Wa 1812, anti-British prints on the wall, which are lit only the moonlight, one more time. He strikes a match to take closer look. When noises outside distract him and he shakes out the ma He goes to the window, pulls back the curtain and looks d below. From his perspective, we see an idling car -- having just been brought from the garage. A uniformed officer waits. Qualters and then Missy come out of the house.

(to Missy) Do you want to drive? Without answering she goes around to the driver's seat; Qualters is telling the officer something. Bertie watches this officer then hurry off. Qualters gets in and drives Missy off. Bertie watches the car go down the long drive; he looks u the moon. He is about to leave the window when a second c is driven up by the Officer, this car is Franklin's. Suddenly the light in the room is turned on, startling Bertie.
I thought you were asleep.
(whispering) Then why did you turn the light on? Outside a car is driving off. Bertie looks out the window
Who’s that?
It’s Franklin. Bertie goes to the wall switch and turns the light off.  82.
Can we call home? I want to speak with Lilibet.
What?? It's--. Looks at the clock.

It's morning there. She's up. We know she's up. They hear another car pull up outside. They look at each other, then both go to the window, pull back the curtains and peek out: THREE WOMEN sit in an idling covertible, as Eleanor hurri from the house and gets into the back seat; there is muff laughter/giggling from the women. The King and Queen watc they drive off:
Who are they? With Eleanor.
I’m just guessing now -- but: the ones who made your bed?
(totally confused) Maids?
The furniture makers.
Oh. Where do you think they’re going, Bertie?
Back to the furniture factory where they all live? I’m just guessing. Then:

I want to call home.  83. INT. DAISY’S BEDROOM. NIGHT Daisy, in a white nightgown, lies in her bed, her bedshee twisted, unable to sleep, staring off toward the window a the full moon. She is restless, tries to lie on a differe side, then reaches and turns on a little bedside lamp, an picks up a book to read.

No one could sleep that night. She impetuously jumps out of bed, grabs a sweater from a on the back of her bedroom door, and goes out, quietly closing the door behind her. We see for the first time, on the back of the door, visib only when closed is a framed official portrait of Preside Roosevelt -- the kind they hang in post offices. EXT. DAISY’S HOUSE PORCH. NIGHT. Daisy swings gently in the porch swing, pushing with her feet; smoking, staring out into the night. The full moon looking down upon her. Suddenly she gets up, quickly stubbing out her cigarette the ashtray. She rushes inside, then quickly stops and gr the screen door to keep it from slamming shut and making noise. EXT. DAISY’S HOUSE / INT. DAISY’S CAR. NIGHT. IN HER CAR, dressed now, she sits in the dark; only the reflection of the moon on the hood of the car; she sighs big sigh and releases the brake and the car rolls a littl Only when it has rolled a comfortable distance from the h does she turn on the engine and then the headlights. And heads off, the moon in front of her, it’s as if she is be pulled by the moon. EXT. PINK BEDROOM. NIGHT. Elizabeth sits on the bed waiting. Bertie comes in from t hallway in his robe.
They're putting us through. Phone in the room rings. Elizabeth answers it.  84.

(into phone) Yes. Yes, put her on. (short pause, then) Darling! It's Mummy! How are you? I'm sure it is. Is Margaret with you? Tell her -- it's still night here. She smiles at Bertie -- Margaret will get a kick out of hearing that, she thinks. But Margaret clearly doesn't understand this concept of t differences. Tell her -- it's night. It's dark. The sun isn't.... What is she saying? Yes I know, it's morning there. But it's... I'm not trying to scare her, dear. Why is what I'm saying scary? The sun will come up, tell her that, just not--. Holding her hand over the phone, to Bertie: She's upset. She's thinks.... I don't know what she thinks. Listens. Now Lilibet’s crying too. He takes the phone.

(into phone) Hello, my Lilibet! Tell your sister it's because the world is round. It goes around the sun so--. It--. (to Elizabeth) They're crying. (what to do? Then into phone) Oh look, the sun has just come out. It was behind a cloud all this time. Tell Margaret that we’re sorry to have confused her. That's right. We're fine. We just wanted to say hello. Lilibet? Lilibet? (to Elizabeth) She's gone. (then) She rung off.  85. INT. DAISY’S CAR / EXT. THE ROAD NEAR TOP COTTAGE. NIGHT. Daisy drives along the main road; she pulls the car onto patch of grass on the side of the road, and cuts the engi She gets out and starts to head into the woods. EXT. WOODS. NIGHT. Daisy climbs, lit only by the moon. She seems to be in no rush to get anywhere -- rather enjoying the night, the magical moonlight, the mystery of the woods, the cries of owls, the barking and howling of distant dogs.

If ever I missed him, there was a place he’d built for me to come, and be alone, and miss him. EXT. TOP COTTAGE. NIGHT. She reaches the top, her destination -- and there is Top Cottage, dark and bathed by the moon. EXT/INT. TOP COTTAGE. NIGHT. Daisy sits on the porch where she has sat so often before with Franklin, and where she now sits looking off at the distant hills. She lights a cigarette and baths in the be of the evening. Behind her, the house is dark; lit only, as is everything else, by the moon. Suddenly through the glass door, we see a shadowy naked female figure scurry, then stop, seem to pick up somethin and for a instant we see her lit, then the lighter is clo and all we see is the glow of her cigarette. Daisy stares off, utterly oblivious to all of this. All of a sudden a flashlight shines in Daisy's face, startling her, and making her jump up. MAN’S VOICE What the hell are you doing here? Daisy, trying to calm herself from the shock, shades her and sees:
Tommy? What the hell are you doing here?  86.
You shouldn’t be up here now.
Why? Why not? Daisy, still covers her eyes.
Can you get that out of my face, please? He lowers the flashlight and she sees, lit now by the flashlight, a pair of shoes on the ground -- women’s blac and white shoes -- Missy’s.
You really shouldn’t be up here, Daisy. Daisy stares at the shoes. Two bare feet appear beside the shoes in the light of the flashlight. It is Missy.

(very friendly) Daisy! How nice to see you up here. ' Daisy looks at Missy, who is finishing a last button; the her bare feet, then at the shoes. A door closes in the house. She turns and looks there, th it all suddenly dawns on her.
Oh my god... Oh my god... She bolts for the woods.
Stop her!
(going after Daisy) Daisy, stop! Don’t go in--. EXT. WOODS. NIGHT. Daisy hurries through the forest.  87. Qualters runs after her, and immediately gets caught in t brambles and trips, falls down.
Fuck. Fuck... Missy follows, still barefoot.

(as she heads into the woods ) Daisy! Ouch. Daisy! EXT. WOODS. NIGHT. Daisy madly fights her way through a brush, then falls an begins sliding, then rolling down a steep hill. EXT. WOODS. NIGHT. Missy fights her way through the underbrush.

(calling) Come on, Daisy! What the hell are you doing? Daisy! EXT. WOODS. NIGHT. Qualters is now sliding down the same hill, holding onto limbs and bushes and he hurries down. EXT. WOODS. NIGHT. Daisy lies on the ground; she hears Missy’s voice. MISSY’S VOICE Daisy! Come on, Daisy! The voice is getting closer. Daisy starts to stand up, wh out of the dark a hand grabs her arm.

I have her! Daisy suddenly bites the arm, pushes away Qualters and plunges into the dark, only to fall again. Qualters flashlight falls onto the trapped Daisy. Missy charges through the brush and hurries to the voice.  88.
Get up. Get up, Daisy. You fucking bit me. What is wrong with you? Daisy is crying, very upset, nearly hysterical.
I said get up. He pulls her up, as Missy appears.
(to Daisy) It’s all right. It’s all right. I understand. Just calm down now.
She fucking bit me.
You'll live. (to Daisy) Take a deep breath. (to Qualters) Let go of her. Let go... Qualters lets go of Daisy.
Now, that’s better isn’t it? Now why are you so upset? Missy tries to touch Daisy’s cheek.
Don’t touch me.

What do you think happened? Missy is breathing heavily. She looks at Qualters then: (desperate) Do you want to see the President? For the first time Daisy looks at her. He’s just up there. I think he’d very much like to see you. Missy picks some leaves and pine needles out of her hair. Look at you. We don’t want him to see you like this, do we?  89. Daisy stares at her. Tommy, could I have your handkerchief? He gives her his handkerchief. She licks it and begins to clean Daisy’s face. As she cleans, and as Daisy stares at her, no longer crying:

This is a very important weekend for everyone. I wouldn’t want any of us to forget that. So we all need to be on our best behavior. Don’t we? Missy continues to fuss, pulling out a leaf from Daisy's tangled hair... Suddenly, Daisy pushes Missy hard; Missy falls, and Daisy bolts again and again charges into the woods.
(on the ground) Daisy!! Get a hold of yourself! Stop this! God damn it! Missy looks at Qualters. Winded, she notices her nose is bleeding.
Don’t look at me. I didn’t do anything. He starts to head back toward the house.

Fuck this, I’m going to stay with the President. EXT. WOODS. NIGHT. Daisy is running, desperate, crying; she fights her way through the bushes. She slips and falls, struggles and hurries to get up and throws herself, down the hill. Anyt to get away. She is a mess; twigs, leaves in her hair; she’s cut her l ripped her dress. She runs recklessly down the hill, tripping, grabbing ont branches to steady herself until she pushes herself out o bush and literally falls onto a road.  90. EXT. THE ROAD NEAR TOP COTTAGE. NIGHT. She looks first one way, and then the other down the road and no more than fifty yards away is her car. Just where left it. EXT. THE ROAD NEAR TOP COTTAGE. NIGHT. She reaches her car, opens the door, gets in, and discove her keys are gone. In a panic, she starts to look on the floor, on the seat when:
Here. Missy is in the backseat, dried blood on her face from he bloody nose. She shows her the keys.
No. Get out of here. Missy reaches and touches Daisy's shoulder.
(shaking her off) Get out of here--
Listen to me, Daisy. No one says anything for a moment, then:
He wants to talk to you.
(shouts ) I don't want to talk to him!! Daisy sits very still.

You're being ... silly. They both notice lights and the noise of a car engine com down the dirt driveway. Daisy doesn’t know what to do; an Missy doesn’t know what Daisy is going to do. As the headlights get closer, Daisy reaches for the door handle, but Missy grabs her arm and holds her.

He’s going home. He’s headed home.  gl. Franklin is being driven by Qualters; the car passes righ Daisy's car, inches away. Franklin in shadow and silhouet is in the backseat; he doesn’t look out. Daisy covers her face. As Franklin’s car drives off, Missy lets go of Daisy’s ar
You want a cigarette? (no response) I want you to listen to me. And I want you to listen very very carefully. Understand? Look at me. Understand? Daisy looks at her.
What can you say?
Understand?
Yes.

I read all your letters, Daisy. And his -- to you. He knows this. Probably wants this... I read the letter where he asks you to live with him. I know you are -- (searches the for the word) intimate. I've known since the day it happened.
What??
Those things he wrote? He meant them. I know that. That hurt. Cigarette? I need one. She lights a cigarette. But I accepted. Like you will.
What do you mean?  92.
I am a part of his life, and I accept that you are too.
I don't accept you.
What about Dorothy Schiff? Do you accept her? (then) Why do you think she has built that place next to Top Cottage?
There are other cottages on that hill--
He asked her to. He asked her to build a cottage, so they could live close together when he retired, while he wrote those goddamn detective books he's always talking about writing.
I don't believe--.
I read the letter.
When was this?
(shrugs ) This year.
No. (then) Why don't you leave him?
For the same reason you won't. Daisy looks out -- into the dawn.
It wasn’t Eleanor who ‘abandoned’ him. She caught him too.
With you?  93.
(laughs ) No. This was -- long ago. Years and years ago. Someone else. He promised never to see her again. Swore on his knees.
Did he? See her again?
She’s been to the White House. Maybe you've met her. Mrs. Rutherford. Daisy looks back out the window.
I’m sorry that I... I misunderstood her. (then) I don't think I can 'share'-
Oh I think you can. You can. She lights both cigarettes and hands one to Daisy.
Thank you. They smoke in silence. Then: She hands Daisy her car keys And she opens the car door.

You decide. Pause. INT. STUDY. NIGHT. Franklin alone; a half-played game of solitaire on his de in front of him. He fiddles with the cards in his hand, h mind elsewhere; he looks at the played cards, begins to s them up to start another game. INT. HALLWAY / LIVING ROOM. NIGHT. A dishevelled Daisy walks down the hallway at Springwood. Franklin’s Mother sits outside of Franklin's study, as if guarding it. She sees Daisy and watches her approach.  94.
(standing) He won't go to bed. He’s waiting for you. Daisy goes into the study without knocking. INT. STUDY. NIGHT. Daisy has sat down.
Would you like a drink?
No. He starts to pour himself one, then decides not to.
